page.title: A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library

{{Infobox book | | name = A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library | image = A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library.jpg | image caption = | author = Alan Coates, Kristian Jensen, Cristina Dondi, Bettina Wagner and Helen Dixon; with the assistance of Carolinne White and Elizabeth Mathew; blockbooks, woodcuts and metalcut single sheets by Nigel F. Palmer; inventory of Hebrew incunabula by Silke Schaeper | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English, [[Latin]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Greek language|Greek]] | subject = Incunabula, Bodleian Library | genre = Short title catalogue | publisher = Oxford University Press | pub_date = 7 July 2005 | media_type = Print | pages = 6 volumes (lxxxvii, 2,165 p.) | isbn = 0199513732 |isbn_note= (set)
0199519056 (vol. 1)
0199519064 (vol. 2)
0199519072 (vol. 3)
0199519080 (vol. 4)
0199519099 (vol. 5)
0199519102 (vol. 6) | oclc = 61755765 | dewey = 016.093 | congress = Z240.A1 B63 2005 }} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library''}} '''''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library''''' (cited as '''Bod-inc.'''Alan Coates, et al., ''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005), p. lxxxvii.) is a [[short-title catalogue]] of more than 5,600 [[Incunable|incunabula]] held in the [[Bodleian Library]] at the [[University of Oxford]]. Bod-inc. stands out among incunabula catalogues for its detailed listing of the contents of each edition being described. It was published on 7 July 2005 by [[Oxford University Press]] in six [[Volume (bibliography)|volumes]]. ==History== L. A. Sheppard began work on a catalogue of Bodleian incunabula in 1955 but he left Oxford in 1971 before the work could be completed; his slip catalogue was bound into seven volumes and served as a base of information for the Bod-inc. project.Alan Coates, et al., ''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005), p. lxx–lxxii. In the mid-1980s, Kristian Jensen, as the Bodleian Library's specialist in early printed books, decided that a new catalogue was needed and that its descriptions should follow the standards of detail expected in catalogues of [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[manuscript]]s.Alan Coates, et al., ''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005), p. lxxii. Early in the project, Jensen was assisted by Bettina Wagner and Alan Coates beginning in 1992. Work on Bod-inc. was undertaken over the thirteen-year period between January 1992 and January 2005 by a team of cataloguers. From 1992 to 1999, Jensen headed the cataloguing team; he was succeeded by Alan Coates who headed the project from 2000 to its completion, during which time Jensen served as a consultant.Alan Coates, et al., ''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005), p. xiii. Bod-inc. was published in the 400th anniversary year of the publication of the first catalogueBodleian Library, ''Catalogus librorum bibliothecae publicae quam vir ornatissimus Thomas Bodleius eques auratus in Academia Oxoniensi nuper instituit'' (Oxford: [[Joseph Barnes (printer)|J. Barnes]], 1605); [[English Short Title Catalogue]] [http://estc.bl.uk/F/?func=find-b&local_base=BLL06&request=S107686&find_code=ESTID record]. of the Bodleian Library in 1605. ==Aims of the catalogue== The aims of Bod-inc. are summarized in the catalogue's introduction: {{quote|text=The main aim of the catalogue has been, from the outset, to combine information about the individual copies in the collections of the Bodleian Library (their [[Bookbinding|bindings]], their [[Provenance#Books|provenance]], manuscript notes, and other signs of use) with a detailed analysis of the contents of each edition, locating all texts in each edition, identifying their [[author]]s, and giving references to modern editions of each text where they exist. It is not the aim of the catalogue to replicate [[Typography|typographical]] information which is already available in one of the other detailed incunable catalogues, such as ''[[Gesamtkatalog der Wiegendrucke|GW]]'', ''BMC'', or Polain.Alan Coates, et al., ''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century now in the Bodleian Library'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005), p. lxxix.}} ==Contents== Bod-inc. is divided into six volumes: ===Volume 1=== *[[Dedication (publishing)|Dedication]] to L. A. Sheppard *[[Preface]] by [[Reginald Carr (librarian)|Reginald Carr]] *List of organizations and individuals who sponsored the cataloguing project *List of members of the cataloguing team *List of academic advisers *[[Acknowledgment (creative arts)|Acknowledgements]] *Bibliographical [[abbreviation]]s *General abbreviations *"The Bodleian Library and Its Incunabula" by Alan Coates *"Form of the Entries in the Catalogue" by Alan Coates and Kristian Jensen *Descriptions by Nigel F. Palmer of [[Block book|blockbooks]] and [[Woodblock printing|woodcut]] and [[metalcut]] [[Broadside (printing)|single sheets]] *Descriptions of incunabula arranged [[Alphabetical order#Alphabetical order|alphabetically]] by author or [[Title (publishing)|title]], A ===Volume 2=== *Descriptions of incunabula arranged alphabetically by author or title, B–C ===Volume 3=== *Descriptions of incunabula arranged alphabetically by author or title, D–H ===Volume 4=== *Descriptions of incunabula arranged alphabetically by author or title, I–O ===Volume 5=== *Descriptions of incunabula arranged alphabetically by author or title, P–S ===Volume 6=== *Descriptions of incunabula arranged alphabetically by author or title, T–Z *Inventory by Silke Schaeper of [[Hebrew incunabula]] *[[Index (publishing)|Indexes]] **Index of authors, [[Translation|translators]], [[Editing|editors]], dedicatees **Index of provenances, owners, [[Donation|donors]], and other names **Index of [[Printer (publisher)|printers]] and [[Publishing|publishers]] *[[Addendum|Appendices]] **Items recorded by Sheppard, but not included in the Catalogue **Items included in [[Incunabula Short Title Catalogue|ISTC]], but excluded from the Catalogue **List of items in Schreiber, ''Woodcuts from Books of the 15th Century'' ==Reviews== *{{cite journal |first=Paul |last=Needham |title=The Bodleian Library Incunables |journal=Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America |volume=101 |issue=3 |date=September 2007 |pages=345–395}} *{{cite journal |first=Richard |last=Sharpe |authorlink=Richard Sharpe (historian) |title=The Present and Future of Incunable Cataloguing, II |journal=The Library |series=7th ser. |volume=9 |issue=2 |date=June 2008 |pages=210–224 |doi=10.1093/library/9.2.210}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/weston/finding-resources/guides/rarebooks/bodleian_incunable_catalogue Bodleian Incunable Catalogue website] – directory of links to [[PDF]] files of the entire text of Bod-inc. in parts *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101129024218/http://www.bodley.ox.ac.uk/dept/scwmss/rarebooks/incfront.html Bodleian Library Incunable Cataloguing Project website] *[https://archive.is/20121213083108/http://lccn.loc.gov/2006272418 Library of Congress Catalog Record] {{books}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Catalogue Of Books Printed In The Fifteenth Century Now In The Bodleian Library}} [[Category:2005 books]] [[Category:Bodleian Library collection]] [[Category:Oxford University Press reference books]] [[Category:Short title catalogues]] [[Category:Incunabula]]

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = A Taste of Greece: Recipes, Cuisine & Culture | name = A Taste of Greece: Recipes, Cuisine & Culture | image = A Taste of Greece 2016.jpg | image_size = | alt = A Taste of Greece | caption = Front cover of ''A Taste of Greece'' | editors = [[Princess Tatiana of Greece and Denmark|HRH Princess Tatiana]], Diana Farr Louis | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = Greek cuisine | genre = Cookbook | country = Greece | published = Germany | publisher = TeNeues | publisher2 = | pub_date = July 2016 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 208 pp. | awards = | isbn = 978-3-8327-3337-7 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = {{URL|http://www.teneues.com/}} }} '''''A Taste of Greece: Recipes, Cuisine & Culture''''' is an illustrated cookbook coordinated by [[Princess Tatiana of Greece and Denmark|Princess Tatiana]] of Greece and edited by the food writer Diana Farr Louis. It is a non-profit publication whose sales benefit the Greek charity [[Boroume]] ("we can!"), supporting food supplies both to refugees in Greece and to Greeks suffering poverty due to the country's economic crisis. The idea of publishing a book of this kind originated with the founder of Boroume, [[Xenia Papastavrou]], according to Maria Karamitsos.<ref>Maria A. Karamitsos, "[http://windycitygreek.com/a-taste-of-greece-supports-boroume/ A Taste of Greece: Cookbook Benefits Boroume]" at ''Windy City Greek'' (13 July 2016)</ref> [[Daisy Dunn]], reviewing ''A Taste of Greece'' in ''[[The Spectator]]'', commented that "Greece’s food crisis has wrought such feelings of exclusion and isolation as can only exist in a culture that has always placed food at the centre of civilisation. Over 17 per cent of the population of Greece is said to be suffering from food insecurity."<ref>Daisy Dunn, "[https://life.spectator.co.uk/2016/08/can-an-ancient-hellenic-concept-solve-greeces-food-crisis/ Can an ancient Hellenic concept solve Greece’s food crisis?]" in ''[[The Spectator]]'' (4 August 2016)</ref>
The book is a collection of favourite Greek recipes contributed by 41 celebrities, chefs and food writers, all of them connected with Greece in different ways. Contributors are arranged alphabetically, but the list includes celebrities such as [[Arianna Huffington]], [[Jim Gianopulos]] of [[20th Century Fox]], writers [[Margaret Atwood]], [[Victoria Hislop]] and [[Sofka Zinovieff]], conductor [[Zubin Mehta]], broadcasters [[Bob Costas]] and [[Nikos Aliagas]], photographer [[Robert McCabe]], actresses [[Rita Wilson]] and [[Olympia Dukakis]]; design and food entrepreneurs such as [[Carole Bamford]], [[Dan Caten|Dan]] and [[Dean Caten]], [[Tatiana Casiraghi]]; chefs [[Michel Roux]], [[Nobu Matsuhisa]], [[Cat Cora]] and Nikos Ntanos who worked on recipes for several other contributors; food writers Diana Farr Louis (who edited the book), Diane Kochilas, Laurie Constantino, Rachel and [[Andrew Dalby]], Peter Minaki. Among the contributors are several members of the ousted [[Greek Royal Family|Greek royal family]] now once again living in Greece: [[Queen Anne-Marie of Greece|Queen Anne-Marie]], her sister-in-law [[Princess Irene of Greece and Denmark|Princess Irene]], her son [[Prince Nikolaos of Greece and Denmark|Prince Nikolaos]] and his wife [[Princess Tatiana of Greece and Denmark|Princess Tatiana]] who coordinated the project. When she was still Tatiana Blatnik she had worked for [[Diane von Furstenberg]], who is a contributor to the book alongside other contacts from the fashion world, [[Mary Katrantzou]], Valentino and [[Giancarlo Giammetti]], as noted by Sharon Edelson writing in ''[[Women's Wear Daily|WWD]]''.<ref>Sharon Edelson, "[http://wwd.com/eye/people/a-princess-publishes-cookbook-for-love-of-country-10446118/ A Princess Publishes a Cookbook for Love of Country]" in ''[[Women's Wear Daily|WWD]]'' (7 June 2016)</ref>
''A Taste of Greece'' was published internationally in July 2016 by TeNeues Media, based in Germany, with branches in the United States, United Kingdom and France.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.boroume.gr/ Boroume], the Greek charity that benefits from book sales * [http://www.boroume.gr/tasteofgreece/ Boroume's page about the book] * [http://www.teneues.com/shop-uk/a-taste-of-greece.html Page about the book] at teNeues
{{DEFAULTSORT:Taste of Greece, The}} [[Category:2016 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Greek cuisine]]

{{About|researcher allegiance||Bias|and|Bias (disambiguation)}} {{Psychology sidebar}} '''Allegiance bias''' (or '''allegiance effect''') in [[Behavioural sciences|behavioral sciences]], denote to the finding or conclusions being crafted in a manner that reconciles best with the investigator's or researcher's perspectives and preferences, instead of retaining its [[Empirical evidence|empirical]], innate or native state.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wilson|first=G. Terence|last2=Wilfley|first2=Denise E.|last3=Agras|first3=W. Stewart|last4=Bryson|first4=Susan W.|date=2017-03-31|year=|title=Allegiance Bias and Therapist Effects: Results of a Randomized Controlled Trial of Binge Eating Disorder|journal=Clinical Psychology |volume=18|issue=2|pages=119–125|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2850.2011.01243.x|issn=0969-5893|pmc=4118818|pmid=25089079|via=}}</ref>
<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Dragioti|first=Elena|last2=Dimoliatis|first2=Ioannis|last3=Evangelou|first3=Evangelos|date=2015-05-30|year=|title=Disclosure of researcher allegiance in meta-analyses and randomised controlled trials of psychotherapy: a systematic appraisal|journal=BMJ Open|volume=5|issue=6|pages=|doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2014-007206|issn=2044-6055|pmc=4458582|pmid=26033943|via=}}</ref>
== Evaluation == <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Staines|first=Graham L.|last2=Cleland|first2=Charles M.|title=Bias in meta-analytic estimates of the absolute efficacy of psychotherapy.|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/?&fa=main.doiLanding&doi=10.1037/1089-2680.11.4.329|journal=Review of General Psychology|volume=11|issue=4|pages=329–347|doi=10.1037/1089-2680.11.4.329}}</ref>
Despite the fact that researchers find the outcomes of psychological evaluations to be influenced from allegiance from a specific school of thought, the role of allegiance in the research field should be evaluated cautiously. Several meta-analyses have shown contradictory results between experimenter’s allegiance (EA) and assessment effect sizes in favor of the preferred conclusions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Dragioti|first=Elena|last2=Dimoliatis|first2=Ioannis|last3=Fountoulakis|first3=Konstantinos N.|last4=Evangelou|first4=Evangelos|date=2015-09-15|year=|title=A systematic appraisal of allegiance effect in randomized controlled trials of psychotherapy|journal=Annals of General Psychiatry|volume=14|pages=|doi=10.1186/s12991-015-0063-1|issn=1744-859X|pmc=4570291|pmid=26379758|via=}}</ref>
=== Psychotherapy === <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Falkenström|first=Fredrik|last2=Markowitz|first2=John C.|last3=Jonker|first3=Hanske|last4=Philips|first4=Björn|last5=Holmqvist|first5=Rolf|date=2013-05-01|year=|title=Can psychotherapists function as their own controls? Meta-analysis of the crossed therapist design in comparative psychotherapy trials|journal=The Journal of Clinical Psychiatry|volume=74|issue=5|pages=482–491|doi=10.4088/JCP.12r07848|issn=1555-2101|pmc=3683365|pmid=23146326|via=}}</ref>
Also, we should not include meta-analysis that examines a combination of psychotherapy and non-psychotherapy treatments (e.g., [[medication]]) if it was directly compared with another type of psychotherapy or meta-analysis evaluating direct comparisons between different types of psychotherapy. Meta-analysis assessing non-verbal techniques, web-based treatments and non-specific or miscellaneous treatments (e.g., [[yoga]], dietary advice, recreation, [[biofeedback]], etc.) should also be excluded.<ref name=":0" />
=== Forensic psychology === Most often [[Forensic psychologist|forensic experts]] indulge in having formed a [[bias]]ed opinion of the assessment in favor of the party retaining their services as opposed to having it objective by means of the evidence available.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.apadivisions.org/division-41/publications/newsletters/news/2014/10/expert-opinion.aspx|title=Identifying and managing potential bias in forensic evaluations|last=|first=|date=|website=APA Div. 41: American Psychology-Law Society|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-31}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Neal|first=Tess M. S.|date=2016-04-28|year=|title=Are Forensic Experts Already Biased before Adversarial Legal Parties Hire Them?|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=11|issue=4|pages=|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0154434|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4849669|pmid=27124416|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeMatteo|first=David|last2=Edens|first2=John F.|last3=Galloway|first3=Meghann|last4=Cox|first4=Jennifer|last5=Smith|first5=Shannon Toney|last6=Formon|first6=Dana|date=2014-06-01|title=The role and reliability of the Psychopathy Checklist-Revised in U.S. sexually violent predator evaluations: a case law survey|journal=Law and Human Behavior|volume=38|issue=3|pages=248–255|doi=10.1037/lhb0000059|issn=1573-661X|pmid=24127888}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeMatteo|first=David|last2=Edens|first2=John F.|last3=Galloway|first3=Meghann|last4=Cox|first4=Jennifer|last5=Smith|first5=Shannon Toney|last6=Formon|first6=Dana|title=The role and reliability of the Psychopathy Checklist—Revised in U.S. sexually violent predator evaluations: A case law survey.|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/?&fa=main.doiLanding&doi=10.1037/lhb0000059|journal=Law and Human Behavior|volume=38|issue=3|pages=248–255|doi=10.1037/lhb0000059}}</ref>
==== Evaluations in Capital Cases ==== <ref>{{Cite journal|last=BA|first=Gianni Pirelli|last2=PhD|first2=Patricia A. Zapf|date=2008-04-16|title=An Investigation of Psychologists' Practices and Attitudes toward Participation in Capital Evaluations|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15228930801947294|journal=Journal of Forensic Psychology Practice|volume=8|issue=1|pages=39–66|doi=10.1080/15228930801947294|issn=1522-8932}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Deitchman|first=Mary Ann|last2=Kennedy|first2=Wallace A.|last3=Beckham|first3=Jean C.|date=1991-06-01|title=Self-selection factors in the participation of mental health professionals in competency for execution evaluations|journal=Law and Human Behavior|volume=15|issue=3|pages=287–303|issn=0147-7307|pmid=11654262}}</ref>
== Analysis == <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leykin|first=Yan|last2=DeRubeis|first2=Robert J.|date=2009-03-01|title=Allegiance in Psychotherapy Outcome Research: Separating Association From Bias|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-2850.2009.01143.x/abstract|journal=Clinical Psychology: Science and Practice|language=en|volume=16|issue=1|pages=54–65|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2850.2009.01143.x|issn=1468-2850}}</ref>
=== Sensitivity === The analysis on direct comparisons did not address the quality of studies and neither did it have any significant association between allegiant and non-allegiant studies; whereas significant differences were observed in cases where treatment ''integrity'' was not evaluated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weisz|first=John R.|last2=Jensen-Doss|first2=Amanda|last3=Hawley|first3=Kristin M.|title=Evidence-based youth psychotherapies versus usual clinical care: A meta-analysis of direct comparisons.|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/?&fa=main.doiLanding&doi=10.1037/0003-066X.61.7.671|journal=American Psychologist|volume=61|issue=7|pages=671–689|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.61.7.671}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wampold|first=Bruce E.|last2=Budge|first2=Stephanie L.|last3=Laska|first3=Kevin M.|last4=Del Re|first4=A. C.|last5=Baardseth|first5=Timothy P.|last6=Fluckiger|first6=Christoph|last7=Minami|first7=Takuya|last8=Kivlighan|first8=D. Martin|last9=Gunn|first9=Wade|date=2011-12-01|title=Evidence-based treatments for depression and anxiety versus treatment-as-usual: a meta-analysis of direct comparisons|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|volume=31|issue=8|pages=1304–1312|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2011.07.012|issn=1873-7811|pmid=21996291}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Munder|first=Thomas|last2=Gerger|first2=Heike|last3=Trelle|first3=Sven|last4=Barth|first4=Jürgen|date=2011-11-01|title=Testing the allegiance bias hypothesis: A meta-analysis|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/10503307.2011.602752|journal=Psychotherapy Research|volume=21|issue=6|pages=670–684|doi=10.1080/10503307.2011.602752|issn=1050-3307|pmid=21797736}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Munder|first=Thomas|last2=Gerger|first2=Heike|last3=Trelle|first3=Sven|last4=Barth|first4=Jürgen|date=2011-11-01|title=Testing the allegiance bias hypothesis: a meta-analysis|journal=Psychotherapy Research|volume=21|issue=6|pages=670–684|doi=10.1080/10503307.2011.602752|issn=1468-4381|pmid=21797736}}</ref>
In legal cases, evaluator attitudes and other attributes may systematically influence from whom evaluators are willing to accept a referral. Filtering and selection effects in adversarial settings have been assumed to exist, but with few empirical tests of the hypothesis to date.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Murrie|first=Daniel C.|last2=Boccaccini|first2=Marcus T.|last3=Guarnera|first3=Lucy A.|last4=Rufino|first4=Katrina A.|date=2013-10-01|title=Are forensic experts biased by the side that retained them?|journal=Psychological Science|volume=24|issue=10|pages=1889–1897|doi=10.1177/0956797613481812|issn=1467-9280|pmid=23969777}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Murrie|first=Daniel C.|last2=Boccaccini|first2=Marcus T.|last3=Guarnera|first3=Lucy A.|last4=Rufino|first4=Katrina A.|date=2013-08-22|title=Are Forensic Experts Biased by the Side That Retained Them?|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0956797613481812|journal=Psychological Science|language=en|volume=24|issue=10|pages=1889–1897|doi=10.1177/0956797613481812}}</ref> Current studies demonstrate that these experts have ''preexisting'' biases that may affect for whom they are willing to work in the adversarial system–thus, likely amplifying the effects of the system-induced biases when layered with preexisting expert biases.
=== Rating === <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gaffan|first=E. A.|last2=Tsaousis|first2=I.|last3=Kemp-Wheeler|first3=S. M.|date=1995-12-01|title=Researcher allegiance and meta-analysis: the case of cognitive therapy for depression|journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology|volume=63|issue=6|pages=966–980|issn=0022-006X|pmid=8543719}}</ref>
== Remedies ==
=== Objective methods === * '''Creating a list''' - this would be the simplest method for a professional to hypothesize all/any possibilities that would seem reasonable, at the inception of an evaluation process.<ref name=":2" /> * '''Surveillance'''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Robinson|first=L. A.|last2=Berman|first2=J. S.|last3=Neimeyer|first3=R. A.|date=1990-07-01|title=Psychotherapy for the treatment of depression: a comprehensive review of controlled outcome research|journal=Psychological Bulletin|volume=108|issue=1|pages=30–49|issn=0033-2909|pmid=2200072}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Imel|first=Zac E.|last2=Wampold|first2=Bruce E.|last3=Miller|first3=Scott D.|last4=Fleming|first4=Reg R.|date=2008-12-01|title=Distinctions without a difference: direct comparisons of psychotherapies for alcohol use disorders|journal=Psychology of Addictive Behaviors|volume=22|issue=4|pages=533–543|doi=10.1037/a0013171|issn=0893-164X|pmid=19071978}}</ref>
=== Disclosures ===
==== Reporting policies ==== Systematic reviews and meta-analysis are essential to summarise evidence relating to efficacy and safety of healthcare interventions accurately and reliably. The clarity and transparency of these reports, however, are not optimal. Poor reporting of systematic reviews diminishes their value to clinicians, policy makers, and other users.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moher|first=David|last2=Tetzlaff|first2=Jennifer|last3=Tricco|first3=Andrea C.|last4=Sampson|first4=Margaret|last5=Altman|first5=Douglas G.|date=2007-03-27|year=|title=Epidemiology and reporting characteristics of systematic reviews|journal=PLoS Medicine|volume=4|issue=3|pages=e78|doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040078|issn=1549-1676|pmc=1831728|pmid=17388659|via=}}</ref>
===== QUOROM ===== {{Main|QUOROM flow chart}} Since the development of the [[QUOROM flow chart|QUOROM]] (quality of reporting of meta-analysis) statement—a reporting guideline published in 1999—there have been several conceptual, methodological, and practical advances regarding the conduct and reporting of systematic reviews and meta-analysis. Also, reviews of published systematic reviews have found that key information about these studies is often poorly reported.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moher|first=D.|last2=Cook|first2=D. J.|last3=Eastwood|first3=S.|last4=Olkin|first4=I.|last5=Rennie|first5=D.|last6=Stroup|first6=D. F.|date=1999-11-27|title=Improving the quality of reports of meta-analyses of randomised controlled trials: the QUOROM statement. Quality of Reporting of Meta-analyses|journal=Lancet|volume=354|issue=9193|pages=1896–1900|issn=0140-6736|pmid=10584742}}</ref>
===== PRISMA ===== {{Main|PRISMA}} Realizing these issues, an international group that included experienced authors and methodologists developed [[PRISMA]] (preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analysis) as an evolution of the original QUOROM guideline for systematic reviews and meta-analysis of evaluations of health care interventions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wen|first=Jin|last2=Ren|first2=Yu|last3=Wang|first3=Li|last4=Li|first4=Youping|last5=Liu|first5=Ya|last6=Zhou|first6=Min|last7=Liu|first7=Ping|last8=Ye|first8=Lu|last9=Li|first9=Yi|date=2008-08-01|title=The reporting quality of meta-analyses improves: a random sampling study|journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology|volume=61|issue=8|pages=770–775|doi=10.1016/j.jclinepi.2007.10.008|issn=0895-4356|pmid=18411041}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jclinepi.com/article/S0895-4356(07)00376-9/abstract|title=The reporting quality of meta-analyses improves: a random sampling study|last=|first=|date=|website=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
[[Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses#The PRISMA statement|The PRISMA statement]] consists of a [[Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses#The PRISMA checklist|27-item checklist]] and a [[Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses#The PRISMA flow diagram|four-phase flow diagram]]. The checklist includes items deemed essential for transparent reporting of a systematic review. In this explanation and elaboration document, they have explained the meaning and rationale for each checklist item & have include an example of good reporting, while also where possible, references to relevant empirical studies and methodological literature.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liberati|first=Alessandro|last2=Altman|first2=Douglas G|last3=Tetzlaff|first3=Jennifer|last4=Mulrow|first4=Cynthia|last5=Gøtzsche|first5=Peter C|last6=Ioannidis|first6=John P A|last7=Clarke|first7=Mike|last8=Devereaux|first8=P J|last9=Kleijnen|first9=Jos|date=2009-07-21|year=|title=The PRISMA statement for reporting systematic reviews and meta-analyses of studies that evaluate healthcare interventions: explanation and elaboration|journal=The BMJ|volume=339|pages=|doi=10.1136/bmj.b2700|issn=0959-8138|pmc=2714672|pmid=19622552|via=}}</ref>
==== Conflict of interest ==== <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thompson|first=Dennis F.|date=2009-01-01|title=The challenge of conflict of interest in medicine|journal=Zeitschrift für Evidenz, Fortbildung und Qualitat im Gesundheitswesen|volume=103|issue=3|pages=136–140|issn=1865-9217|pmid=19554887}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK22942/|title=Conflict of Interest in Medical Research, Education, and Practice|last=Institute of Medicine (US) Committee on Conflict of Interest in Medical Research, Education, and Practice|date=2009-01-01|publisher=National Academies Press (US)|isbn=9780309131889|editor-last=Lo|editor-first=Bernard|series=The National Academies Collection: Reports funded by National Institutes of Health|location=Washington (DC)|pmid=20662118|editor-last2=Field|editor-first2=Marilyn J.}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maj|first=Mario|date=2008-08-01|title=Non-financial conflicts of interests in psychiatric research and practice|journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry |volume=193|issue=2|pages=91–92|doi=10.1192/bjp.bp.108.049361|issn=0007-1250|pmid=18669986}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maj|first=Mario|date=2008-08-01|title=Non-financial conflicts of interests in psychiatric research and practice|url=http://bjp.rcpsych.org/content/193/2/91|journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry|language=en|volume=193|issue=2|pages=91–92|doi=10.1192/bjp.bp.108.049361|issn=0007-1250|pmid=18669986}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roseman|first=Michelle|last2=Milette|first2=Katherine|last3=Bero|first3=Lisa A.|last4=Coyne|first4=James C.|last5=Lexchin|first5=Joel|last6=Turner|first6=Erick H.|last7=Thombs|first7=Brett D.|date=2011-03-09|title=Reporting of conflicts of interest in meta-analyses of trials of pharmacological treatments|journal=JAMA|volume=305|issue=10|pages=1008–1017|doi=10.1001/jama.2011.257|issn=1538-3598|pmid=21386079}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Roseman|first=Michelle|date=2011-03-09|title=Reporting of Conflicts of Interest in Meta-analyses of Trials of Pharmacological Treatments|url=http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/646062|journal=JAMA|language=en|volume=305|issue=10|doi=10.1001/jama.2011.257|issn=0098-7484}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Lieb|first=Klaus|last2=von der Osten-Sacken|first2=Jan|last3=Stoffers-Winterling|first3=Jutta|last4=Reiss|first4=Neele|last5=Barth|first5=Jürgen|date=2016-04-26|year=|title=Conflicts of interest and spin in reviews of psychological therapies: a systematic review|journal=BMJ Open|volume=6|issue=4|pages=|doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2015-010606|issn=2044-6055|pmc=4853969|pmid=27118287|via=}}</ref>

page.title: Arabian Hall of the Winter Palace

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.4)
revision.text:
[[File:Arab Dining.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Arabian Hall with one of the Tsar's four "Ethiopians", by [[Konstantin Ukhtomsky]] (1860s)]]
[[File:Sdining roomWinter Pal.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Location of the Arabian Room within the Winter Palace]]
The '''Arabian Hall''', sometimes known as the Blackamoor Hall or the Arabian Dining Room, is one of the [[Private Apartments of the Winter Palace|private rooms of the Winter Palace]] in [[Saint Petersburg]]. In the [[Tsar]]ist era, it was the room from which imperial processions through the [[state room]]s began. The double doors<ref>The doors in the wall on the right in the watercolor, largely hidden by the flanking columns, opened into the enfilade.</ref> were designed to be on a straight axis through the principal state rooms and ultimately the [[Jordan Staircase of the Winter Palace|Jordan Staircase]], forming an [[Enfilade (architecture)|enfilade]]. Thus it was here the [[House of Romanov|Romanov family]] often assembled, in private, before state receptions and occasions.<ref>Maylunas.</ref> The privacy of the room was not compromised by the small private courtyard (''see plan'') from which windows, which once led to the [[:Image:Hau WinterGarden.jpg|Tsaritsa's winter-garden below]], admitted light.
Designed by [[Alexander Briullov]] following the Winter Palace fire of 1837, the room is decorated in the [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical]] style fashionable in the early 19th century, known as [[Pompei]]an. A ceiling, with a low segmental [[barrel vault]] with bands of shallow [[coffer]]ing [[stucco]]ed with classical motifs, is seemingly supported by a [[colonnade]] of engaged fluted [[Doric order|Greek Doric]] columns with enriched [[Ovolo|echinus]] molding and no bases.<ref>The State Hermitage Museum.</ref> A [[Meander (art)|Greek key]] fret enriches the [[entablature]] that runs without a break round the room. The only furnishings were the dining chairs of Greek [[klismos]] type, formally ranged round the walls. When the Imperial family were to dine here, dining tables would be brought in, covered and laid, then removed afterwards.<ref>[[Dining table]]s on massive central pedestals, left in place in the dining room, were an English innovation of the second quarter of the nineteenth century.</ref>
The various geographically confused names of the Arabian Hall derive, not from any peculiar contents, but from the four official pseudo-bodyguards of the Tsar who travelled from palace to palace with the Imperial family. They were four "massive Negroes" fantastically dressed in scarlet trousers, gold jackets, white turbans and curved shoes.<ref>Massie, p. 129.</ref> Wherever the Tsar was, they guarded the doors between the private and official world. They had no other function other than to open and close doors; their sudden, but silent appearance into a room was the signal that heralded the immediate appearance of the Tsar or [[Tsaritsa]].
Although the guards were referred to as the [[People of Ethiopia|Ethiopians]] or [[wiktionary:Blackamoor|Blackamoor]]s, from 1896, at least one was an American. Jim Hercules holidayed in the USA and always returned with jars of [[Guava|guava jelly]] for the Imperial children.<ref>All information concerning the "Ethiopians" is from Massie, p. 129.</ref>
Today, the empty hall is occasionally used for special exhibitions held by the [[State Hermitage Museum]].
== Notes == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/sftrajan/2991580411/ The same view of the Arabian Hall today] Flickr. Retrieved 13 November 2008.
== References ==
*{{cite book | last = Cowles | first = Virginia | year = 1971 | title = ''The Romanovs'' | publisher = William Collins, Sons & Company Ltd. | location = London | isbn = 000211724X }}
* Massie, Robert K. ''Nicholas and Alexandra''. Atheneum. New York. 1967. *{{cite book | last = Maylunas, Andrei | first = Mironenko, Sergei | year = 1996 | title = ''A Lifelong Passion'' | publisher = Weidenfeld and Nicolson | location = London | isbn = 0-297-81520-2 }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081211013538/http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/05/hm5_4_2_1_3.html The State Hermitage Museum] retrieved 23 September 2008. Published by The State Hermitage Museum.
{{The Winter Palace}}
[[Category:Hermitage Museum]]

{{Infobox NRHP | name =Austin History Center
(NRHP: Austin Public Library) | nrhp_type = | image = Austin history center 2006.jpg | caption = The Austin History Center main entrance | locmapin = Texas#USA | location= 810 Guadalupe St
[[Austin, Texas]], [[United States|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|16|17|N|97|44|44|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built = {{Start date|1933}} | architect = [[Hugo Kuehne]]
[[J. Roy White]] | architecture = [[Renaissance Revival]] | added = May 6, 1993 | governing_body = Austin Public Library | refnum=93000389{{NRISref|2006a}} | designated_other1=RTHL | designated_other1_date=1993 | designated_other1_number=[https://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5453006425 6425] | designated_other1_num_position= bottom }} The '''Austin History Center''' is the local history collection of the [[Austin Public Library]] and the city's historical archive. The building opened as the official Austin Public Library in 1933 and served as the main library until 1979, when library functions moved to the [[John Henry Faulk]] Library, a newer facility next door. Its site, which overlooks one of four public squares platted in Austin in 1839, was obtained from the [[Texas Legislature]] in 1913 for construction of a public library. The [[Renaissance Revival]] structure, completed in 1933, was designed by local architect [[J. Roy White]],{{Cite web|title=J. Roy White Drawings|website=Texas Archival Resources Online|publisher=[[University of Texas at Austin]]|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/aushc/00316/ahc-00316.html|accessdate=July 17, 2017}} working for the architectural firm of Austin native [[Hugo Kuehne]], founding dean of the [[University of Texas]] School of Architecture. The building also contains work by several Austin craftsmen, including ironworker Fortunat Wiegl, wood-carver Peter Mansbendel, and [[fresco]] artist Harold "Bubi" Jessen.{{Cite web|title=Details for 1933 Austin Public Library (Atlas Number 5453006425)|website=[[Texas Historical Commission]]|url=https://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5453006425|accessdate=July 17, 2017}} The Austin History Center celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2005. As of 2008 it houses thousands of documents, photographs, maps, artifacts, and personal histories. It features special exhibits and speakers on a regular basis. [[File:AustinHistoryCenter.JPG|thumb|left|View of the Austin History Center]] The historic library building was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on May 6, 1993.{{Cite web|title=Austin Public Library|website=[[National Register of Historic Places]]|url=https://npgallery.nps.gov/AssetDetail/NRIS/93000389|accessdate=July 17, 2017}} A [[Texas Historical Commission]] marker placed in front of the library identifies it as a Texas Historic Landmark recorded in 1993. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Austin History Center}} * [http://www.austinhistorycenter.org Austin History Center] * [http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/viewform.asp?atlas_num=2093000389&site_name=Austin+Public+Library&class=2001 Texas Historical Commission] * [http://teachinghistory.org/history-content/website-reviews/23175 Teachinghistory.org review of AHC website ''Austin Treasures''] {{Downtown Austin}} {{National Register of Historic Places in Austin, Texas}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1933]] [[Category:Archives in the United States]] [[Category:City of Austin Historic Landmarks]] [[Category:History centers]] [[Category:History museums in Texas]] [[Category:Museums in Austin, Texas]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Austin, Texas]] [[Category:Libraries on the National Register of Historic Places in Texas]] [[Category:Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks]] [[Category:1933 establishments in Texas]]

{{more citations needed|date=February 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox film |name = Austin Powers in Goldmember |image = Austin Powers in Goldmember.jpg |caption = Theatrical release poster |director = [[Jay Roach]] |producer = {{Plainlist| * Jan Blenkin * John S. Lyons * Eric McLeod * [[Demi Moore]] * [[Mike Myers]]}} |screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Mike Myers * [[Michael McCullers]]}} |based on = {{Based on|[[List of Austin Powers characters|Characters]]|Mike Myers}} |starring = {{Plainlist| * Mike Myers * [[Beyoncé Knowles]] * [[Seth Green]] * [[Michael York]] * [[Robert Wagner]] * [[Mindy Sterling]] * [[Verne Troyer]] * [[Michael Caine]]}} | music = [[George S. Clinton]] | cinematography = [[Peter Deming]] | editing = {{Plainlist| * Greg Hayden * [[Jon Poll]]}} | studio = {{Plainlist| Gratitude International
Team Todd
Moving Pictures}} |distributor = [[New Line Cinema]] |released = {{Film date|2002|7|26}} |runtime = 98 minutes |country = United States |language = English |budget = $63 million |gross = $296.7 million}} '''''Austin Powers in Goldmember''''' is a 2002 American [[spy film|spy]] [[Action comedy|action comedy film]] directed by [[Jay Roach]], and the third installment in the [[Austin Powers|''Austin Powers'' film series]]. It stars [[Mike Myers]] in the [[Austin Powers (character)|title role]], and was co-written by him and [[Michael McCullers]]. Myers also plays the roles of [[Dr. Evil (character)|Dr. Evil]], [[Johann van der Smut|Goldmember]], and [[Fat Bastard (character)|Fat Bastard]]. The movie co-stars [[Beyoncé]] in her theatrical film debut, as well as [[Robert Wagner]], [[Seth Green]], [[Michael York (actor)|Michael York]], [[Verne Troyer]], [[Michael Caine]], [[Mindy Sterling]] and [[Fred Savage]]. There are a number of [[cameo appearance]]s including [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Kevin Spacey]], [[Britney Spears]], [[Quincy Jones]], [[Tom Cruise]], [[Danny DeVito]], [[Katie Couric]], [[Gwyneth Paltrow]], [[John Travolta]], [[Nathan Lane]], and [[The Osbournes]]. In a self-parody of the ''Austin Powers'' series, there is a [[Film in a film|film within the film]] in the opening. Austin Powers is featured in a [[bio-pic]] called ''Austinpussy'' (a parody of the [[James Bond]] film ''[[Octopussy]]'') directed by [[Steven Spielberg]] and starring [[Tom Cruise]] as Austin Powers, [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] as Dixie Normous, [[Kevin Spacey]] as Dr. Evil, [[Danny DeVito]] as Mini-Me, and [[John Travolta]] as Goldmember. ''Goldmember'' is a loose parody of the James Bond films ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' and ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'', also incorporating elements of ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]'', ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'', ''[[The Man with the Golden Gun (film)|The Man with the Golden Gun]]'' and ''[[GoldenEye]]''.{{Citation needed lead|date=August 2017}} The film grossed $296.6 million at the box office internationally. ==Plot== {{Long plot|section|date=August 2017}} In his new headquarters behind the famous [[Hollywood]] sign, [[Dr. Evil]] plans to travel back in time to 1975 and bring back [[Johan van der Smut]], aka "Goldmember", who developed a [[cold fusion]] unit for a [[tractor beam]] which Dr. Evil names "[[Preparation H]]". He intends to use the tractor beam to pull a meteor into the Earth, striking the polar ice caps and causing a global flood. Moments after this plan is revealed, [[Austin Powers (character)|Austin Powers]] and the British Secret Service attack the base and arrest Dr. Evil. Austin is knighted for his services, but is disappointed when his father, the famous super-spy Nigel Powers, does not attend the event. [[Basil Exposition]] later informs Austin that Nigel has been kidnapped, and the only clue is that the crew of his yacht have had their genitalia painted gold. Austin visits the imprisoned Dr. Evil, who tells him that Goldmember is behind the abduction. Time-travelling to 1975, Austin infiltrates Goldmember's [[roller disco]] club and is reunited with his former lover, FBI agent Foxxy Cleopatra, who is undercover as a disco singer. With Foxxy's help, Austin locates his father, but is unable to rescue him. Goldmember takes Nigel through Dr. Evil's time machine into the present day. Foxxy wants revenge on Goldmember for murdering her partner, and accompanies Austin in his pursuit. In the present, Dr. Evil and Mini-Me instigate a riot in their prison, allowing them to escape. A British Intelligence [[mole (espionage)|mole]] named Number 3 informs Austin that Dr. Evil has moved to a new lair near Tokyo. Austin and Foxxy travel to Tokyo and confront [[Fat Bastard (character)|Fat Bastard]], who is now a [[sumo wrestling|sumo wrestler]], but still does work for Dr. Evil. Fat Bastard explains that a Japanese business man, [[Nobu Matsuhisa|Mr. Roboto]], is working on a device for Dr. Evil and Goldmember. Austin and Foxxy later meet with Mr. Roboto, who pleads ignorance about Nigel's whereabouts. Unconvinced, Austin and Foxxy infiltrate Roboto's factory where the command unit for the tractor beam is being loaded in Goldmember's car, and Roboto hands Goldmember a golden key needed to activate the beam. Foxxy confronts Goldmember while Austin attempts to free Nigel, but Goldmember escapes with the command unit and flees to Dr. Evil's submarine. Unable to settle their differences, Nigel and Austin part ways when they disagree on how to deal with the situation. Meanwhile, Dr. Evil's son, [[Scott Evil]], has become increasingly evil in an attempt to prove himself to his father, to the point that he too is going bald. Scott presents his father with sharks with laser beams attached to their heads, a request that had gone unfulfilled in [[Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery|the first film]]. Dr. Evil replaces Mini-Me with Scott as his favored son; the rejected Mini-Me defects and joins Austin. Austin, Foxxy and Mini-Me (now a miniature version of Austin) infiltrate the submarine, but Austin is captured. Dr. Evil prepares to activate the tractor beam, but Foxxy has stolen the key and frees Austin. Austin prepares to shoot Dr. Evil, when Nigel appears and reveals that Austin and Dr. Evil are both his sons, telling them that when they were babies, he and their mother took them to Belgium for a family holiday and he stepped out of the car to have a tinkle in the bushes when their car exploded. Dr. Evil tells him that his parents died in that car accident, but Nigel reveals that the explosion came from an assassination attempt and he thought at first that only Austin survived and didn't know that Dr. Evil survived too until after the two Belgians made him evil. Dr. Evil and Austin embrace, enraging Scott, who flees to pursue his own vengeance, whilst Goldmember commandeers the tractor beam's controls, unzipping his pants to reveal his gold-covered genitals to be a spare key. Goldmember activates the tractor beam, but Austin and Dr. Evil work together to reverse its polarity, destroying the meteor and saving the world. The heroes arrest Goldmember, who turns to the camera to reveal the entire string of events was [[story within a story|adapted into a film]] by [[Steven Spielberg]], starring [[Tom Cruise]] as Austin, [[Kevin Spacey]] as Dr. Evil, [[Danny DeVito]] as Mini-Me, and [[John Travolta]] as Goldmember. Austin, Foxxy, Dr. Evil, Mini-Me and Nigel are in the audience of a Hollywood theater watching the film. Upon exiting the theater they run into Fat Bastard, now thinner but flabby, thanks to the [[Subway diet]]. As Austin and Foxxy kiss, in Dr. Evil's Hollywood lair, Scott – now completely bald, dressed like and laughing in a manner similar to his father – declares he will get his revenge on Austin and begins dancing like [[Michael Jackson]]. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Mike Myers]] as [[Austin Powers (character)|Austin Powers]], a British agent. :Myers's other roles in the film include: :*[[Dr. Evil]], a Belgian [[supervillain]] and Austin Powers’ nemesis and long-lost twin brother. :*[[Fat Bastard (character)|Fat Bastard]], a Scottish former [[Ministry of Defence]] soldier who now works as a Japanese sumo wrestler. :*[[Goldmember]], a Dutch supervillain, henchman of Dr. Evil and the main antagonist of the film. ** [[Aaron Himelstein]] as young Austin Powers ** [[Josh Zuckerman]] as young Dr. Evil * [[Beyoncé|Beyoncé Knowles]] as Foxxy Cleopatra,{{cite news|title= Golden Girl: Beyonce's Glittering Film Debut Destined to Turn Heads, and Makeup Trends|work= [[The Hartford Courant]]|date=|url= http://articles.courant.com/2002-07-26/features/0207260848_1_goldmember-nigel-powers-austin-powers|accessdate=2010-11-06}} Austin's new sidekick and Goldmember's rival * [[Michael York]] as [[Basil Exposition]], Austin's boss ** Eddie Adams as young Basil Exposition * [[Michael Caine]] as [[Nigel Powers]]{{cite news|title= Michael Caine: The original Austin Powers|work= CNN|date=July 26, 2002|url= http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/Movies/07/26/caine.cnna/index.html|accessdate=2010-11-06}} a British agent and Austin's father ** [[Scott Aukerman]] as young Nigel Powers * [[Robert Wagner]] as [[Number 2 (Austin Powers)|Number Two]], Dr. Evil's henchman ** [[Rob Lowe]] as Middle Number Two ** [[Evan Farmer]] as Young Number Two * [[Seth Green]] as [[Scott Evil]], Dr. Evil's son * [[Verne Troyer]] as [[Mini-Me]], Dr. Evil's mini doppelganger * [[Mindy Sterling]] as [[Frau Farbissina]], Dr. Evil's wife * [[Fred Savage]] as [[Characters of Austin Powers|Number Three / Mole]] * [[Brian Tee]] as Godzilla Pedestrian * [[Masi Oka]] as Godzilla Copyright Pedestrian * [[Clint Howard]] as [[Austin Powers (series)#Minor Characters|Radar Operator Johnson Ritter]] * [[Michael McDonald (comedian)|Michael McDonald]] as Royal Guard * [[Donna D'Errico]] as Female Vendor * [[Fred Stoller]] as Melon Guy * [[Greg Grunberg]] as the shirtless fan with the letter "T" (Greg's brother Brad Grunberg is the fan with the "A") * [[Kinga Philipps]] as Mrs. Powers * [[Kevin Stea]] as Assistant Director of "Austinpussy" / Dancer * [[Anna-Marie Goddard]], [[Nina Kaczorowski]], and [[Nikki Ziering]] as henchwomen * [[Ming Tea]] as Themselves * [[Rachel Roberts (model)|Rachel Roberts]] as The Model * [[Susanna Hoffs]] as Gillian Shagwell * [[Matthew Sweet]] as Sid Belvedere * [[Christopher Ward (songwriter)|Christopher Ward]] as Trevor Algberth * [[Carrie Ann Inaba]] as Fook Yu * [[Diane Mizota]] as Fook Mi * [[Nathan Lane]] as Mysterious Disco Man * [[Katie Couric]] as Prison Guard * [[Tom Lister Jr.]] as Prisoner #2 * [[Kristen Johnston]] as Dancer at Austin's pad * [[Heather Graham]] as [[Felicity Shagwell]] (uncredited) ===Cameos=== * [[Tom Cruise]] as himself as Austin Powers (during ''Austinpussy'') * [[Danny DeVito]] as himself as Mini-Me (during ''Austinpussy'') * [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] as herself as Dixie Normous (during ''Austinpussy'') * [[Kevin Spacey]] as himself as Dr. Evil (during ''Austinpussy'') * [[Steven Spielberg]] as himself * [[Quincy Jones]] as himself * [[John Travolta]] as himself as Goldmember (during the ''Austinpussy'' ending) * [[Britney Spears]] as herself as Fembot ("[[Boys (Britney Spears song)|Boys]]" music video) * [[Ozzy Osbourne]] as himself * [[Sharon Osbourne]] as herself * [[Kelly Osbourne]] as herself * [[Jack Osbourne]] as himself * [[Willie Nelson]] as himself * [[Burt Bacharach]] (during the credits) as himself * [[Neil Mullarkey]] as Physician * [[Nobu Matsuhisa]] as Mr. Roboto * Masa Kanome as Mr Roboto's Student * Hideo Kimura as Security Guy * Hiroshi Otaguru as Security Man * Nate Kanae as Sumo Wrestler * Peter Navy Tuiasosopo as Sumo Wrestler with Beard {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Title concerns=== The title of the film, ''Goldmember'', led to legal action being taken by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM]], the distributors of the [[James Bond (franchise)|''James Bond'' film franchise]], that briefly led to the film's title being removed from promotional material and trailers. The dispute was quickly resolved and the film title remained unchanged on the provision that the film would include trailers in its cinema releases for the then-upcoming James Bond film, ''[[Die Another Day]]'', and ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2002/2002-04-10-bond-powers.htm|title=Spy vs. spy ends amicably|work=USA Today|accessdate=2007-04-07 | date=2002-04-10}} ===Characters=== [[Austin Powers (character)|Austin Powers]] (Myers), having conquered the '90s and the '60s, travels back to the 1970s and teams up with his nemesis [[Dr. Evil]] (also played by Myers) to thwart a new villain, Goldmember (Myers once again). Myers also plays [[Fat Bastard (Austin Powers Character)|Fat Bastard]] for the second time, this time [[parody]]ing the kind of [[Wire fu|"wire fight"]] seen in ''[[Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon]]''. The film also stars Beyoncé Knowles as [[Foxxy Cleopatra]] (parodying [[blaxploitation]] heroines, primarily [[Foxy Brown (film)|Foxy Brown]] and [[Cleopatra Jones]], as well as [[Get Christie Love!|Christie Love]] when she says, "You're under arrest, sugah!"), [[Michael York (actor)|Michael York]], reprising the role of Basil Exposition, and [[Verne Troyer]] in his second appearance as [[Mini-Me]]. The film also introduced a new character named Number 3 (a.k.a. the Mole), who is portrayed by former [[child actor|child star]] [[Fred Savage]]. [[Clint Howard]] plays a radar operator in all three films. [[Michael Caine]] guest stars as Austin's father, Nigel; this role was inspired by ''[[The Ipcress File]]'', a 1965 film starring Caine.{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2006/01/05/the_ipcress_file_2006_review.shtml | title=The Ipcress File (1965) | publisher=BBC | date=January 6, 2006 | accessdate=June 17, 2013 | author=Leyland, Matthew}} Four actors who appeared in the earlier films play different characters in ''Goldmember''.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} [[Rob Lowe]], who played the friend of a dead guard in ''International Man of Mystery'', reprises his role as a younger Number 2 from ''The Spy Who Shagged Me'', while [[Neil Mullarkey]] (quartermaster clerk in ''International Man of Mystery'') and Eric Winzenried (army private soldier in ''The Spy Who Shagged Me'') appear as the Physician and Henchman Sailor in the Sick Bay. [[Michael McDonald (comedian)|Michael McDonald]] (the Virtucon guard who got run over by a steamroller in "International Man of Mystery" and a NATO soldier in "The Spy Who Shagged Me") appears as the royal guard.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} ====Goldmember==== '''[[Johan van der Smut]]''', better known as '''Goldmember''', is a fictional villain played by Myers ([[John Travolta]] plays the character in a cameo at the end of the film). The name was inspired by the [[James Bond]] villain [[Auric Goldfinger]]. Goldmember's Dutch origins and character traits were, according to Myers, inspired by an episode of the [[HBO]] TV series ''[[Real Sex]]'' featuring a Dutchman who operated a "sex barn" north of [[Rotterdam]]. The man's distinct forms of expression caught Myers' attention while he was writing.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2002-07-25-goldmember_x.htm |work=USA Today|title=Movie news|date=2002-07-25 | first1=Andy | last1=Seiler | accessdate=2010-04-25}} ==Release== ===Box office=== ''Austin Powers in Goldmember'' took in [[Pound sterling|£]]5,585,978 in the United Kingdom on its opening weekend.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} In the United States, it broke the opening weekend record for a spoof movie, surpassing the previous Austin Powers film.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} The film grossed US$73 million on its opening weekend, and grossed a total of $213 million in the United States, according to [[Box Office Mojo]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} ===Home media=== ''Austin Powers in Goldmember'' was released on video and DVD on December 3, 2002.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} The DVD was released under the ''[[Infinifilm]]'' label, and was re-packed in 2011 as part of the ''Austin Powers 3 Film Collection'' ===Critical reaction=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film received a rating of 54%, based on 183 reviews, with the site's critical consensus reading, "While the narrative structure is messy and doesn't make much sense, the third installment of the ''Austin Powers'' franchise contains enough inspired bits to entertain".{{cite web|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=December 20, 2009|title=Austin Powers in Goldmember (2002) Reviews|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/austin_powers_in_goldmember/}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 62 out of 100, based on 34 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews". Myers was nominated for the [[MTV Movie Award]] for [[MTV Movie Award for Best Villain|Best Villain]] for the third time, but lost against [[Daveigh Chase]] for her role as Samara Morgan in ''[[The Ring (2002 film)|The Ring]]'', making it the first time Myers lost the award.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} However, he did win the award for [[MTV Movie Award for Best Comedic Performance|Best Comedic Performance]], making it the first time he won the award, having previously lost twice for the first two films.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} ===Awards=== {{See also|List of accolades received by the Austin Powers franchise}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; font-size:90%;" |- ! Award ! Category ! Name ! Outcome |- | [[2003 MTV Video Music Awards]] || Best Video From a Film || "[[Boys (The Co-Ed Remix)]]" by [[Britney Spears]] (feat. [[Pharrell]]) || {{nom}} |- | [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI Film & Television Awards]] || BMI Film Music Award || [[George S. Clinton]] || {{won}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Black Reel Awards of 2003]] || Best Breakthrough Performance || [[Beyoncé|Beyoncé Knowles]] || {{nom}} |- | Best Song || Beyoncé Knowles, [[Work It Out (Beyoncé Knowles song)|"Work It Out"]] || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Canadian Comedy Awards]] || Film – Pretty Funny Male Performance || [[Mike Myers]] || {{won}} |- | Film – Pretty Funny Writing || Mike Myers || {{won}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Empire Awards|Empire Awards 2003]] || Best Actor || Mike Myers || {{nom}} |- | Scene of the Year || The opening sequence || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="3"| [[Golden Satellite Awards 2002]] || [[Satellite Award for Best Costume Design|Best Costume Design]] || Deena Appel || {{nom}} |- | [[Satellite Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]] || "Work It Out" || {{nom}} |- | Best Overall DVD || || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| Hollywood Makeup Artist and Hair Stylist Guild Awards || Best Character Hair Styling – Feature || Candy L. Walken, Jeri Baker, Susan V. Kalinowski || {{nom}} |- | Best Period Hair Styling – Feature || Candy L. Walken, Jeri Baker, Susan V. Kalinowski || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="4"| [[2003 Kids' Choice Awards]] || Favorite Movie || || {{won}} |- | Favorite Female Butt Kicker || Beyoncé Knowles || {{nom}} |- | Favorite Male Movie Star || Mike Myers || {{nom}} |- | Favorite Fart in a Movie || || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="3"| [[2003 MTV Movie Awards]] || [[MTV Movie Award for Best Comedic Performance|Best Comedic Performance]] || Mike Myers || {{won}} |- | [[MTV Movie Award for Best Villain|Best Villain]] || Mike Myers || {{nom}} |- | Best Female Breakthrough Performance || Beyoncé Knowles ||{{nom}} |- | [[Saturn Award|29th Saturn Awards]] || [[Saturn Award for Best Costume|Best Costume]] || Deena Appel || {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[2003 Teen Choice Awards]] || Choice Movie Actor: Comedy || Mike Myers || {{nom}} |- | Choice Movie: Female Breakout Star || Beyoncé Knowles || {{nom}} |} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Austin Powers in Goldmember: Music from the Motion Picture | type = soundtrack | artist = various artists | cover = Album-APIG.jpg | released = {{Start date|2002|7|16}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Disco]]|[[funk]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[Rock music|rock]]}} | length = {{duration|m=62|s=30}} | label = [[Maverick Records|Maverick]] | producer = {{hlist|Danny Bramson|John Houlihan}} | chronology = ''[[Austin Powers (film series)|Austin Powers]]'' series | prev_title = [[Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (soundtrack)|Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me]] | prev_year = 2002 | misc = {{Singles | name = Austin Powers in Goldmember | type = soundtrack | single1 = [[Work It Out (Beyoncé song)|Work It Out]] | single1date = June 11, 2002 | single2 = [[Boys (Britney Spears song)|Boys]] | single2date = July 29, 2002 }}}} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[AllMusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/austin-powers-in-goldmember-original-soundtrack-mw0000225232 |title=Austin Powers in Goldmember [Original Soundtrack] – Original Soundtrack |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=November 17, 2016}} | noprose = yes }} The song "Hey Goldmember" interpolates and is a parody of four 1970s [[disco]] songs formed into a [[medley (music)|medley]]; "[[Sing a Song (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Sing a Song]]" by [[Earth, Wind & Fire]], "[[Get Down Tonight]]", "[[(Shake, Shake, Shake) Shake Your Booty]]", and "[[That's the Way (I Like It)]]", all by [[KC and the Sunshine Band]]. "Sing a Song" is not listed in the credits but is sung by [[Beyoncé]] at the beginning. ===Track listing=== # "[[Work It Out (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Work It Out]]" – [[Beyoncé]] # "[[Miss You (The Rolling Stones song)|Miss You]]" ([[Dr. Dre]] Remix 2002) – [[The Rolling Stones]] # "[[Boys (Britney Spears song)|Boys]]" (Co-Ed Remix) – [[Britney Spears]] featuring [[Pharrell Williams]] of [[N.E.R.D]]) # "[[Groove Me]]" – [[Angie Stone]] # "[[Shining Star (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Shining Star]]" – [[Earth, Wind & Fire]] # "Hey Goldmember" – [[Beyoncé|Foxxy Cleopatra]] featuring [[Devin the Dude|Devin]] and [[Solange Knowles|Solange]] # "Ain't No Mystery" – [[Smash Mouth]] # "[[Evil Woman (Electric Light Orchestra song)|Evil Woman]]" – Soul Hooligan featuring [[Diana King]] # "1975" – [[Paul Oakenfold]] (samples "[[A Fifth of Beethoven]]" by [[Walter Murphy]]) # "[[Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)]]" (Dr. Evil Remix) – [[Dr. Evil]] # "Daddy Wasn't There" – [[Ming Tea]] featuring [[Austin Powers (character)|Austin Powers]] # "[[Alfie (Burt Bacharach song)|Alfie]] (What's It All About, Austin?)" – [[Susanna Hoffs]] ===Charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2002) ! scope="col"| Peak
position |- {{album chart|Australia|34|artist=Soundtrack|album=Austin Powers: Goldmember|rowheader=true|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} |- {{album chart|IrelandComp|6|year=2002|week=33|rowheader=true|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} |- {{album chart|New Zealand|25|artist=Soundtrack|album=Austin Powers: Goldmember|rowheader=true|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} |- {{album chart|UKSoundtrack|1|date=20020804|rowheader=true|accessdate=October 31, 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/austin-powers-in-goldmember-original-soundtrack-mw0000225232/awards |title=Austin Powers in Goldmember [Original Soundtrack] – Original Soundtrack {{!}} Awards |publisher=AllMusic |accessdate=October 31, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126143159/http://www.allmusic.com/album/austin-powers-in-goldmember-original-soundtrack-mw0000225232/awards |archivedate=January 26, 2016}} | 27 |- ! scope="row"| US [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] (''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'') | 46 |- ! scope="row"| US Soundtrack Albums (''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'') | 1 |} ==Possible sequel== In October 2005, in an interview with ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', Mike Myers discussed the possibility of studio sources moving forward with a fourth film. "There is hope!". "We're all circling and talking to each other. I miss doing the characters."{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1114708,00.html |title=Mike Myers may return to ''Austin Powers'' |publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} In May 2007, in an interview with [[IGN]], "So no more ''Austin Powers''?" was asked, and Myers replied, "No, no, there is a fully conceived idea for a fourth and I can just say that it's from Dr. Evil's point of view. So if you balanced how much of it was Austin with Dr. Evil, it's more about Dr. Evil than Austin".{{cite web|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/788/788829p2.html |title=IGN: Interview: Mike Myers and Antonio Banderas |publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} Also, in the audio commentary from the DVD release of ''Goldmember'', Myers revealed that in the fourth film, [[Fat Bastard (character)|Fat Bastard]] would return and regain the weight that he lost in ''Goldmember''.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/news/austin-powers-needs-kill-fat-bastard-wbna44147655|title='Austin Powers' needs to kill off Fat Bastard|publisher=}} In May 2007, at the ''[[Shrek the Third]]'' première, Mike Myers announced that a fourth ''Austin Powers'' film was planned, but that it would focus more on [[Dr. Evil]] rather than [[Austin Powers (character)|Austin]]. He also said that he'd start work on it after he started work on ''[[The Love Guru]]'', which became a [[box office bomb]].{{cite web|title=Mike Myers Revives Dr. Evil, Plus Kirsten Dunst, 'High School Musical' & More, In Movie File|date=8 May 2007|first=Shawn|last=Adler|url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1559113/20070501/story.jhtml|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} In February 2008, it was announced that [[Jay Roach]] would return as director. In April 2008, it was reported that [[Gisele Bündchen]] had been offered a role in the film.{{cite web|title=Is Gisele Bundchen the Next ‘Austin Powers’ Girl?|date=14 April 2008|first=B. Alan|last=Orange|url=http://movieweb.com/is-gisele-bundchen-the-next-austin-powers-girl/|publisher=[[Movieweb.com]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} However, [[Seth Green]], who played [[Scott Evil]], state that there was any script at the moment and that ''Austin Powers 4'' would be made if a script is written and approved.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2429982/sorry-giselle-but-austin-powers-4-still-isnt-happening-says-seth-green/#more-2191|title=Sorry Giselle But 'Austin Powers 4’ Still Isn't Happening, Says Seth Green|publisher=}} In June 2008, in an interview, when asked about another ''Austin Powers'' film, Myers stated, "I have an idea, and again it's one of those things that will emerge or it won't."{{cite news|url=http://www.latinoreview.com/news.php?id=4813 |title=Mike Myers on Love Guru, Shrek 4, Austin 4 and Wayne's World|publisher=[[Latino Review]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} In July 2008, Mike Myers stated that he had begun writing ''Austin Powers 4'', and that the plot is "really about Dr. Evil and his son."{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/mike-myers-is-writing-austin-powers-4/ |title=Mike Myers is Writing Austin Powers 4|publisher=[[Slashfilm]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} In March 2010, [[Jay Roach]] indicated to [[MTV]] that Myers is working on ideas for a fourth film.{{cite web|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2010/03/22/fourht-austin-powers-movie-will-go-somewhere-you-havent-though-of-jay-roach-says/ |title=Fourth 'Austin Powers' Movie Will Go 'Somewhere You Haven't Though Of,' Jay Roach Says|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=2010-10-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1559113/20070501/story.jhtml|title=Mike Myers Revives Dr. Evil|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=2007-05-09}} In August 2011, Mike Myers revealed he would return, and had begun writing a script for a fourth installment.{{cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/blogs/motion-captured/posts/exclusive-mike-myers-is-signed-sealed-delivered-and-austin-powers-04-is-coming |title=Exclusive: Mike Myers is signed, sealed, delivered for 'Austin Powers 4'|publisher=[[Hitfix]]|accessdate=2015-04-26}} In September 2013, when asked about the future of ''Austin Powers'', Myers answered "I'm still figuring that out."{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/09/toronto-fleming-qas-supermensch-helmer-mike-myers-on-shep-gordon-pic/ |title=Toronto: Fleming Q&A’s Mike Myers On 'Supermensch' Directorial Debut|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} In September 2015, [[Verne Troyer]] expressed his desire to return as [[Mini-Me]] if he was asked to do so.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/entertainment/verne-troyer-waiting-for-the-call-for-austin-powers-4-697306.html|title=Verne Troyer waiting for the call for Austin Powers 4|date=September 23, 2015|publisher=}} On May 20, 2016, Roach was asked about the fourth ''Austin Powers'' film during an interview with [[Larry King]], and he stated the ideas for the fourth film that he and Myers have are good and interesting.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/film/austin-powers-4-could-still-happen-according-to-di-885106|title=Austin Powers 4 could still happen, according to director Jay Roach - NME|date=May 20, 2016|publisher=}} In August 2016, in a telephone interview, Mike Myers stated "Everything is being negotiated and worked out and all that stuff" in regards to the fourth installment of the ''Austin Powers'' film series.{{cite web |url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/1391580-mike-myers-talks-waynes-world-the-leafs-austin-powers |title=Mike Myers talks 'Wayne's World,' the Leafs, 'Austin Powers' |author=The Canadian Press |date=25 August 2016 |publisher=[[The Chronicle Herald]] |access-date=27 August 2016}} In April 2017, as the twentieth anniversary approached for ''[[Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery]]'', Mike Myers claimed he would love to do another ''Austin Powers'' film, but audiences would "just have to see".{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/austin-powers-4-new-film-movie-mike-myers-interview-a7707001.html|title=Austin Powers 4: 'I would love to do another' Mike Meyers says as original turns 20|publisher=independent.co.uk|date=28 April 2017|accessdate=26 May 2017}} Two days later, Roach stated that a fourth film would only occur if Myers creates a good story for it.{{cite web|url=http://www.darkhorizons.com/jay-roach-on-why-theres-no-austin-powers-4/|title=Jay Roach On Why There's No "Austin Powers 4" - Dark Horizons|website=www.darkhorizons.com}} On May 26, 2017, Troyer stated that Mini-Me will reveal that he can speak in the fourth movie.{{cite web|url=http://www.mymbuzz.com/2017/05/26/verne-troyer-teases-austin-powers-4-mini-me-will-speak/|title=Verne Troyer teases Austin Powers 4: Mini Me will speak!|date=May 26, 2017|publisher=}} However, Troyer died on April 21, 2018, delaying production of a fourth film and precluding him from reprising his role as Mini-Me.{{cite web|url=http://people.com/movies/verne-troyer-dies-at-49/|title=Austin Powers Star Verne Troyer Dies at 49|publisher=}} On May 9, 2018, Myers reiterated his interest in making a fourth ''Austin Powers'', stating that it would be fun, also hinting that some tribute to Troyer might be included.https://news.sky.com/story/new-austin-powers-film-is-a-very-strong-maybe-says-mike-myers-11364974 ==See also== * [[Outline of James Bond]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0295178}} * {{mojo title|austinpowers3}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|austin_powers_in_goldmember}} * {{metacritic film|austin-powers-in-goldmember}} {{Austin Powers movies}} {{Jay Roach}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Austin Powers 3}} [[Category:Austin Powers|3]] [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:2000s action comedy films]] [[Category:2000s parody films]] {{Infobox Court Case | name = Bell v. the State | court = [[Supreme Court of Georgia (U.S. state)|Supreme Court of Georgia]] | image = Flag of Georgia (U.S. state).svg | date_filed = | date decided = July 9, 1971 | full name = | citations = 227 Ga. 800, 183 S.E.2d 357 (1971) | judges = | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = [http://www.lawskills.com/case/ga/id/13914 unofficial copy] | transcripts = }} '''Bell v. the State of Georgia''', 227 Ga. 800, 183 S.E.2d 357 (1971) is one of several cases in which the [[Supreme Court of Georgia (U.S. state)|Supreme Court of Georgia]] set forth the standard by which an extraordinary [[motion (legal)|motion]] for a [[new trial]] is to be judged.
In order for a defendant to succeed when making such a motion after having discovered [[new evidence]], the defendant must show
{{quote| #that the evidence has come to his knowledge since the trial; #that it was not owing to the want of due diligence that he did not acquire it sooner; #that it is so material that it would probably produce a different verdict; #that it is not cumulative only; #that the affidavit of the witness himself should be procured or its absence accounted for; and #that a new trial will not be granted if the only effect of the evidence will be to impeach the credit of a witness.}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawskills.com/case/ga/id/13914 |title=Bell v. the State |work=lawskills.com |publisher=EastCore, INC |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725032216/http://www.lawskills.com/case/ga/id/13914/ |archivedate=2008-07-25 |df= }}</ref> These six criteria have appeared in a number of other decisions of the [[Supreme Court of Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia Supreme Court]], including ''[[Timberlake v. the State]]'' and the majority opinion in ''Davis v. the State'' (see [[Troy Anthony Davis]]).
The case stemmed from an appeal for a conviction centered on child [[hearsay]] testimony. This court decision and similar ones in the same and other [[U.S. state]]s are designed to ensure the finality of [[jury]] [[verdict]]s. It is therefore necessary for [[defense lawyer]]s to present all [[exculpatory]] evidence at trial rather than bringing such evidence before the courts in a piecemeal manner; however, some<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/document.php?lang=e&id=ENGAMR510232007|title="Where is justice for me?" The case of Troy Davis, facing execution in Georgia|publisher=Amnesty International USA}}</ref> have criticized the principle of finality of jury verdicts as increasing the possibility of errors in [[death penalty]] cases.
== Sources == <references/>
[[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) case law]] [[Category:U.S. state criminal procedure case law]] [[Category:1971 in United States case law]] [[Category:1971 in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:United States hearsay case law]]
{{US-case-law-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Émile Vandervelde 1919.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Émile Vandervelde]], pictured in 1919, played an influential role in drafting the Charter]] The '''Charter of Quaregnon''' ({{lang-fr|Charte de Quaregnon}}, {{lang-nl|Charter van Quaregnon}}) was a [[political manifesto]] which formed the doctrinal basis of [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[socialism]] from 1894 until 1979.
In 1894, Belgian elections were for the first time held according to the scheme of the [[Plural voting|plural right to vote]] under the pressure of the violent [[Belgian general strike of 1893]]. This meant for the [[Belgian Labour Party]] (POB-BWP), that for the first time workers could vote and that representatives from the party, ten years after its foundation, could enter the [[Belgian Federal Parliament|Belgian parliament]]. With a doctrinarian charter the program of the socialist party was presented to the electorate. Out of several ideas [[Émile Vandervelde]] chose this proposition, which was adopted on the [[Easter]] Congress of the Socialist Party, at [[Quaregnon]] on 25-26 March 1894, and which became known as the ''Charter of Quaregnon''. This charter was strongly influenced by ideas of the [[France|French]] socialist [[Jules Guesde]].
As a doctrinal source of inspiration for the Belgian Socialists, the Charter of Quaregnon remained in place for two [[World War]]s and many years. Only after 1979, when the [[Belgian Socialist Party]] (PSB-BSP) divided into the [[Flanders|Flemish]] ''[[Socialistische Partij Anders|Socialistische Partij]]'' (SP) and the [[Wallonia|Walloon]] ''[[Socialist Party (francophone Belgium)|Parti Socialiste]]'' (PS), newer charters were created.
==Text of the charter== {{quotation| {{center|Charter of Quaregnon}} ----
* 1. [[Wealth]] in general, and the [[means of production]] in particular, are [[natural resources]], or the result of manual- or intellectual labour of former generations, as well as of the present generation; consequently they must be considered as the common heritage of all humanity. * 2. Only for reasons of social benefit and with the goal to provide as much freedom and well-being to every human, it is allowed to provide people or groups with separate rights to that common heritage. * 3. The realisation of this ideal brings with it of course the disappearance of the [[capitalism|capitalist]] scheme, which divides society into two hostile [[Social class|classes]]: one that [[Bourgeoisie|without working can enjoy property]]; the other which is [[Proletariat|obliged to cede part of its produce to the ruling class]]. * 4. Workers can only expect their liberation from the abolition of classes and a thorough reorganisation of society. This reform will not be exclusively for the benefit of the proletariat, but for the whole of humanity; however because it is opposed to the immediate interests of the ruling classes, the liberation of the workers must be mainly the work of the workers themselves. * 5. On a material level the goal must be to gain the free use of all results of production. This goal is only possible in a society where collective work replaces more and more individual work, which means the [[Social ownership|collective use of natural resources and means of production]]. * 6.The conversion of the capitalist scheme into a [[collectivistic]] scheme of course must be accompanied by herewith coherent reforms: ** 1. On a moral level, by developing charity and observing [[solidarity]]. ** 2. On a political level, by transforming the [[Sovereign state|state]] towards a management of resources. * 7. Socialism must observe therefore at the same time the material, moral and political liberation of the workers. Nevertheless material liberation must be the main goal, because the concentration of capital in the hands of some classes already determines the basis of the other forms of the predominance. }}
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926235453/http://www.lsp-mas.be/marxisme/2005gesarbbew2.html Inleiding tot de geschiedenis van de Belgische arbeidersbeweging] * Th. Luykx and M. Platel, Politieke geschiedenis van België, 2 vol., Kluwer, 1985 * E. Witte, J. Craeybeckx en A. Meynen, Politieke geschiedenis van België, Standaard, 1997
==See also== * [[Henri de Man|Plan De Man]] (1933) * [[The Communist Manifesto]] * [[Oxford Manifesto]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722042719/http://www.socialisme.be/marxisme/2005gesarbbew2.html Inleiding tot de geschiedenis van de Belgische arbeidersbeweging] (Dutch)
{{navigation sp.a}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Croan|Crohn|Krone (disambiguation)}} {{original research|date=May 2015}} {{Wiktionary|crone}} The '''crone''' is a [[stock character]] in [[folklore]] and [[fairy tale]], an old woman. In some stories, she is disagreeable, malicious, or sinister in manner, often with magical or supernatural associations that can make her either helpful or obstructing. The Crone is also an archetypal figure, a [[Wise Old Man and Wise Old Woman|Wise Woman]]. As a character type, the crone shares characteristics with the [[hag]]. The word "crone" is a less common [[synonym]] for "old woman", and is more likely to appear in reference to traditional narratives than in contemporary everyday usage.Based on a [[Google]] search of "crone" (2,510,000 hits) and "old woman" (about 16,700,000). Additional data from a search of the ''New York Times'' archives since 1981 which yielded 9100 results for "crone" and 10,023 for "old woman"; in the period 1851–1980, 4,137 for "crone" and 12,270 for "old woman." Searches did not sort out the surname "Crone," nor the construction "N-year-old woman." Retrieved 29 March 2009. The word became further specialized as the third aspect of the [[Triple Goddess (Neopaganism)|Triple Goddess]] popularized by [[Robert Graves]] and subsequently in some forms of [[neopaganism]], particularly [[Wicca]] in which she symbolizes the Dark Goddess, the dark of the moon, the end of a cycle; together with the Mother and the Maiden she represents part of the circle of life. In [[New Age]] and [[feminist]] spiritual circles, a "[[Croning]]" is a [[ritual]] [[rite of passage]] into an era of wisdom, freedom, and personal power. Some feminist authors have defined the crone archetype in a positive light, as a powerful and wise old woman. Barbara G.
